Situation1: They are asked to take part in an important family event like a holiday celebration or trip.
Situation2: A patient with a chronic autoimmune disease requires a very specific and ongoing treatment plan.
Story:
I stared at my phone, the group chat buzzing with excitement about the upcoming family trip. My stepbrother sent a message: “Can’t wait to have you with us this year!” My stepmother chimed in, reminding me how much it would mean to everyone if I joined. I knew how important it was to show up, to be present, to prove I was part of this family, not just an outsider.

But as I scrolled through my emails, a new message from the hospital appeared. One of my patients, a young woman with a rare autoimmune disease, needed her medication adjusted. The pharmacy was out of stock, and she was running low. The attending physician was away, and the responsibility fell to me. If I didn’t act quickly, her health could deteriorate.

My heart pounded. I could almost hear my stepmother’s voice, disappointed if I missed another family event. At the same time, I felt the weight of my patient’s trust, her life depending on my decisions. I sat at my desk, torn between the family I was trying to belong to and the oath I had sworn as a doctor, feeling the pressure of both worlds closing in.
